item.title: Cloud tech makes sense on-prem too
item.description: I can spin up new VMs on the server in my living room and install software on it. But it's more complex than just installing the software on a baremetal server. Fortunately for me, cloud technologies such as opentofu, cloud-init, and ansible can let me spin up and configure local VMs in seconds.

item.title: The Parallelism Mesh Zoo : ezyang’s blog
item.description: When training large scale LLMs, there is a large assortment of parallelization strategies which you can employ to scale your training runs to work on more GPUs. There are already a number of good resources for understanding how to parallelize your models: I particularly recommend How To Scale Your Model and The Ultra-Scale Playbook. The purpose of this blog post is to discuss parallelization strategies in a more schematic way by focusing only on how they affect your device mesh. The device mesh is an abstraction used by both PyTorch and JAX that takes your GPUs (however many of them you've got in your cluster!) and organizes them into a N-D tensor that expresses how the devices communicate with each other. When we parallelize computation, we shard a tensor along one dimension of the mesh, and then do collectives along that dimension when there are nontrivial dependencies between shards. Being able to explain why a device mesh is set up the way it is for a collection of parallelization strategies is a good check for seeing if you understand how the parallelization strategies work in the first place! (Credit: This post was influenced by Visualizing 6D Mesh Parallelism.)

item.title: Relative frequency of SI units and prefixes – Negative Feedback
item.description: I am huge a fan of the SI system, but I’ve often noticed that even my academic colleagues take a mix-and-match aproach to the BIPM standards. It is common for chemists to use Ångstrom over nanometre, and I don’t think I’ve ever seen anyone use megagram over tonne.
